The LTT 3780 Exoplanetary System

LTT 3780 is a star with 0.4 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.37 times its radius. It is located 71.69 light years away from the solar system.

LTT 3780 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

LTT 3780 b

LTT 3780 b was discovered by the Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite (TESS) observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2020-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.01 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 0.77 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, LTT 3780.

In the case of Earth, these numbers are 0.9832899 and 1.0167103 respectively.

The mass of LTT 3780 b is 2.62 times the mass of Earth. The radius of LTT 3780 b is 1.332 that of Earth. At 2.62 Earth masses, LTT 3780 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
